verses.text: Then the LORD said to Moses, “Go in to Pharaoh and say to him, ‘This is what the LORD, the God of the Hebrews, says: Let my people go, so that they may serve me.
verses.comment: No significant differences. Kept 'serve' instead of more modern 'worship' for word-for-word accuracy.

verses.text: For if you refuse to let them go and continue to hold them,
verses.comment: Direct translation; 'hold' rather than 'keep' to reflect stubbornness.

verses.text: then the hand of the LORD will come with a very severe plague upon your livestock that are in the field: the horses, the donkeys, the camels, the herds, and the flocks.
verses.comment: 'Plague' chosen as main rendering of the Hebrew 'dever.'

verses.text: But the LORD will make a distinction between the livestock of Israel and the livestock of Egypt, and nothing that belongs to the Israelites will die.”
verses.comment: 'Distinction' follows Hebrew 'palah.'

verses.text: And the LORD appointed a set time, saying, “Tomorrow the LORD will do this thing in the land.”
verses.comment: Literal translation 'appointed a set time'.

verses.text: The next day the LORD did this. All the livestock of Egypt died, but not one of the animals belonging to the Israelites died.
verses.comment: Clarified 'animals belonging to the Israelites' for readability; meaning unchanged.

verses.text: So Pharaoh sent, and indeed, not even one of the livestock of Israel had died. But Pharaoh’s heart was hardened, and he did not let the people go.
verses.comment: Used 'was hardened' rather than 'became hard' for accuracy.

verses.text: Then the LORD said to Moses and Aaron, “Take handfuls of soot from a kiln, and let Moses scatter it toward the sky in the sight of Pharaoh.
verses.comment: 'Kiln' used for 'furnace' in Hebrew; 'scatter' is literal.

verses.text: It will become fine dust over all the land of Egypt, and will cause boils breaking out with sores on people and animals throughout the land of Egypt.”
verses.comment: Phrase 'boils breaking out with sores' clarified; meaning preserved.

verses.text: So they took soot from a kiln and stood before Pharaoh, and Moses scattered it toward the sky. It became boils breaking out with sores on people and animals.
verses.comment: Literal translation; modern phrasing for 'breaking out with sores.'

verses.text: The magicians could not stand before Moses because of the boils, because the boils were on the magicians and on all the Egyptians.
verses.comment: Used 'magicians' for Hebrew 'hartummim.'

verses.text: But the LORD hardened Pharaoh’s heart, and he did not listen to them, just as the LORD had said to Moses.
verses.comment: Maintained traditional phrasing 'hardened Pharaoh’s heart.'

verses.text: Then the LORD said to Moses, “Rise up early in the morning and present yourself before Pharaoh, and say to him, ‘This is what the LORD, the God of the Hebrews, says: Let my people go, so that they may serve me.
verses.comment: Repeated earlier phrase for consistency and accuracy.

verses.text: For this time I will send all my plagues upon you, your servants, and your people, so that you may know there is no one like me in all the earth.
verses.comment: Literal translation; 'plagues upon you'.

verses.text: For by now I could have stretched out my hand and struck you and your people with a plague so that you would have been wiped off the earth.
verses.comment: 'Wiped off the earth' renders Hebrew 'destroyed from the earth.'

verses.text: But, for this reason I have kept you, to show you my power and to declare my name throughout all the earth.
verses.comment: 'Kept you' translates Hebrew idiom for 'raised you up.'

verses.text: Still, you exalt yourself against my people by refusing to let them go.
verses.comment: 'Exalt yourself' is literal; reflects Pharaoh’s pride.

verses.text: Look, tomorrow about this time I will cause very heavy hail to fall, such as has not been seen in Egypt since the day it was founded until now.
verses.comment: 'Since the day it was founded' for 'since its founding.'

verses.text: Now therefore, send and bring your livestock and all that you have in the field to safety. Every person or animal that is in the field and is not brought in will die when the hail falls on them.”
verses.comment: 'To safety' clarifies 'secure places;' meaning unchanged.

verses.text: Those among Pharaoh’s servants who feared the LORD’s word made their servants and livestock flee into the houses.
verses.comment: Literal rendering; 'fled into the houses.'

verses.text: But those who did not regard the word of the LORD left their servants and livestock in the field.
verses.comment: 'Regard' for 'pay attention to.'

verses.text: Then the LORD said to Moses, “Stretch out your hand toward heaven, so that hail may fall over all the land of Egypt, on people and animals and on every plant of the field throughout the land of Egypt.”
verses.comment: Literal rendering; 'Stretch out your hand toward heaven.'

verses.text: So Moses stretched out his staff toward heaven, and the LORD sent thunder and hail, and fire ran down to the earth. And the LORD rained hail upon the land of Egypt.
verses.comment: 'Fire ran down' – Hebrew unclear; possibly lightning. Presented literal meaning.

verses.text: There was very severe hail—fire flashing in the midst of the hail—such as had never been in all the land of Egypt since it became a nation.
verses.comment: 'Became a nation' clarifies 'from its founding.'

verses.text: The hail struck down everything that was in the field in all the land of Egypt, both human and animal. The hail struck down every plant of the field and broke every tree of the field.
verses.comment: Literal rendering; 'struck down' is direct translation.

verses.text: Only in the land of Goshen, where the Israelites lived, there was no hail.
verses.comment: Clarified 'where the Israelites lived.'

verses.text: Then Pharaoh sent for Moses and Aaron and said to them, “This time I have sinned. The LORD is righteous, and I and my people are wrong.
verses.comment: 'Wrong' for 'wicked'—rendered for current idiom, but Hebrew is 'wicked.'

verses.text: Pray to the LORD, for there has been enough of God’s thunder and hail. I will let you go, and you shall stay no longer.”
verses.comment: Literal rendering; 'Pray to the LORD.'

verses.text: Moses said to him, “As soon as I have gone out of the city, I will stretch out my hands to the LORD; the thunder will cease, and there will be no more hail, so that you may know the earth belongs to the LORD.
verses.comment: 'Belongs to the LORD' for 'is the LORD’s.'

verses.text: But as for you and your servants, I know that you still do not fear the LORD God.”
verses.comment: 'Fear the LORD God' retains original meaning.

verses.text: Now the flax and the barley were destroyed, for the barley was in the ear and the flax was in bud.
verses.comment: 'Ear' is literal for barley; modern phrasing.

verses.text: But the wheat and the spelt were not destroyed, for they ripen late.
verses.comment: Added 'ripen late' for clarity.

verses.text: So Moses went out from Pharaoh, out of the city, and stretched out his hands to the LORD. The thunder and hail stopped, and the rain was no longer poured on the earth.
verses.comment: Includes all elements; 'no longer poured' is literal.

verses.text: But when Pharaoh saw that the rain, hail, and thunder had ceased, he sinned again and hardened his heart, he and his servants.
verses.comment: Kept 'hardened his heart,' matching Hebrew.

verses.text: So Pharaoh’s heart was hardened, and he did not let the Israelites go, just as the LORD had spoken through Moses.
verses.comment: Literal wording; closing of the plague narrative.
